subject: Add design for authorities list management
commitMessage:
Add design for authorities list management

To support authorities list, we propose to add two interfaces to the
Authority Manager (the authority type of certificate manager):
1. InstallAll
2. ReplaceAll

Signed-off-by: Nan Zhou <nanzhoumails@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I9a26765c4162d515c8bc6ae1e8544e36cbbf0f14

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.
Uploaded patch set 2.
Uploaded patch set 3.
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 4:

PTAL.

Originally my idea is to create a new cert type (trust bundle). After talking to Ed, using existing cert object is cleaner and can be used by parties other than Google (and gRPC).

However, we still need the changes proposed in this design.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 5d8e3d8cf6fee54197521513df1f3932b16b60d2
This sounds like slang. ;)
Done

Doesn't AUTHORITY_CERTIFICATES_LIMIT set the number of certs that are allowed?  In looking at the interfaces, it looks like it supports multiple today, and checks for things like uniqueness:

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-certificate-manager/blob/71957992588d1b239c33ba25cf713b48b4014521/certs_manager.cpp#L176

Maybe that's just what you mean by "good way" ?

Yeah, it does support installation of multiple certs, one at a time. 

I explained what it lacks in the following two points. Basically "bulk install" and "bulk replace" are missing. 

I can rephrase "google way" if that introduces ambiguity.
typo, "google way" should be "good way"
Please fix line wraps throughout the doc.
Done. Went with 79 cols.
What is the comma for here?  Should it be a period or colon?
Done
does redfish support this interface so that clients can call it?

No. CertificateService doesn't provide this action in the latest Redfish schema. Proposing a corresponding Redfish action is not in the scope of this proposal. 

The purpose of proposing the "ReplaceAll" interface is only for other BMC services that can talk to  CertManager via DBus.
What service do you intend to use this interface then?  bmcweb?
For now, it will be a Google internal daemon.
Sentences should not begin with "And".
Done
when do you think clients would want to delete there certificates and install new ones? is it during the first time when system is setup?

That's a good question.

Inside Google, we have use cases when we need to replace the certificates bundle in a non-disruptive way (BMC keeps running but services get their certs bundle refreshed). So, this method is not only used during the system boot up.

Takes _an_ input PEM?

Prefer Oxford comma after PEM.
Done
Interfaces seem reasonable, and changes seem relatively minimal.
Ack
You mean 'enhance' and not 'change'?
Done

I found out that we still need an InstallAll interface, since the original Install interface returns only a single string for the create Certificate DBus object path.

I also added more details about the behavior of the InstallAll and ReplaceAll interfaces.

PTAL. 

Compared to the last version which I got +1s, the latest patchset added InstallAll to install authorities list.
I have some minor comments that I'd prefer were addressed.
I think this is a statement about what the solution is, not what the problem is? If so, IMO this should be discussed towards the end of the section, if it's even necessary at all.
Done
IMO the "Problem Description" section is the place to write down these use cases. Can you please expand on them?
Done
This is the kind of content I like to see here. Thanks!
Ack

IMO it's best to leave the implementation details such as the specific applications out of the system-level requirements. I think you can specify the behaviour you want without mentioning them here, but I'm not requiring you make that change.
Done, I moved some details into the Proposed Design section.
This is where we would talk about the implementation specifics I mentioned above.
Done

IMO this section should be about second-order effects of the change. As you're proposing new interfaces there probably aren't any, but what you've written here sort of just restates what you've already said above. If there aren't any second-order (or higher) effects, then I think it would be best just to say "None" here to avoid the duplication.
Done

What happened to the "Alternatives Considered" section? This section is meant to strengthen the argument for your proposed design by eliminating the bad ideas off-the-bat, which should help avoid architectural disagreements in code review.
Done
Thanks for the detailed review. PTAL

Thanks for the updates, I think they've helped refine the style. I do have some follow-up comments and queries though. Particularly, I'd like to see discussion on the question of using file descriptors instead of paths in the API.
Thanks for adding the example use-case. This helped me understand the motivation.
Please trim all trailing whitespace throughout the document.
Ack.
Done. I need to change my editor :)
I think this captures the problem nicely now. Thanks for reworking it.
Ack
instantiated
Done
recover
Done
Again, thanks for reworking the above section, it's good.
Ack
Gah, I hate that this is abbreviated (not your fault, just venting)
Ack. This aligns with existing fold in PDI.
Delete this?
Done.

Have you considered passing a file descriptor instead? We have some interfaces in the BMC that pass paths and the experience drawn frin this is that descriptors are better in a lot of circumstances. Particularly around who deletes files when.

Does InstallAll take a path argument also? Because if so, consider whether that should be consistent with ReplaceAll wrt using a file descriptor.

That's a very good suggestion! I heard this from Ed as well. These two interfaces are pretty the extended version of the existing "Install" and "Replace", which takes path strings. 

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Certs/Install.interface.yaml
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Certs/Replace.interface.yaml

Also, ReplaceAll takes the path of the new file, not take an input of existing files. 

The existing implementation in phosphor-certificate-manager is tightly coupled with string path. I would image taking a FD instead requires considerable changes.

Plus, this design is consistent with existing interfaces and at least is not getting things worse. 

With that said, I will consider file descriptors in the future, but not this time. 

Are you OK with putting "file descriptor" as a good-to-have thing in the future?

> That's a very good suggestion! I heard this from Ed as well. These two interfaces are pretty the extended version of the existing "Install" and "Replace", which takes path strings. 
> 
> https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Certs/Install.interface.yaml
> https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Certs/Replace.interface.yaml

Ah, okay. Bummer.

> 
> Also, ReplaceAll takes the path of the new file, not take an input of existing files. 

I'm not sure how this impacts my suggestion?

> 
> The existing implementation in phosphor-certificate-manager is tightly coupled with string path. I would image taking a FD instead requires considerable changes.

Can you expand on this a little more? Why would it be so much work? At the worst you could just open the file right before you call the DBus API right?

> 
> Plus, this design is consistent with existing interfaces and at least is not getting things worse. 

I disagree, adding more of an anti-pattern is making things worse :) It's just not adding new classes of anti-pattern.

> 
> With that said, I will consider file descriptors in the future, but not this time. 
> 
> Are you OK with putting "file descriptor" as a good-to-have thing in the future?

I'm not sure. I've asked for feedback from others in discord: https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/867820390406422538/930664406260523078

> > Also, ReplaceAll takes the path of the new file, not take an input of existing files.
> I'm not sure how this impacts my suggestion?
Oh, since you mention that FD is pretty useful "around who deletes files when". I was saying that all the arguments here are files to be read, not deleted.

> Can you expand on this a little more? Why would it be so much work? At the worst you could just open the file right before you call the DBus API right?

Oh, I thought I need to fix exiting codes. 

Yeah, I could test how FD works. Do you have some examples?

Also it worths mentioning that in the current plan, our internal consumers of these APIs will be shell scripts + daemons. If we use FD, it involve some redesign in Google internally (I assume shell scripts won't work anymore).

> I'm not sure. I've asked for feedback from others in discord: https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/867820390406422538/930664406260523078

Thanks. My preference was to go with path string. Then I can take the effort to migrate all codes and all docs in certificate-manager, bmcweb, and anywhere these APIs get referenced to FD if all other maintainers think that's the right direction. I already did some codes cleaning in the PR chain (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-certificate-manager/+/50011/3)

Ed left a comment here that suggests paths are fine in this case: https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/867820390406422538/930881438830694431. As such I think this discussion point is resolved.
Again, if necessary, consider using file descriptors
See above.
I know I reviewed this part away in the previous patch, but who will consume these new APIs? bmcweb for redfish? If so, it should be listed here? Is IPMI impacted?
It will used by Google's downstream daemons which makes dbus calls to install certificates. If BMCWeb needs multiple root certificates, it can use the InstallAll interface as well.

Do you have a link to documentation on trust bundles? Who has defined what they are?

So I guess there's some inertia due to lack of definition in redfish, but are trust bundles the correct solution if effort wasn't a problem?

Apologize, no public documents about the trust bundle. But in Google's use case, we leverage gRPC heavily, and gRPC takes a list of root certificate for its mTLS channel. 

e.g. https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/etc/roots.pem
existing unit testing in phosphor-certificate-manager? If so can you state that here explicitly? Just so there's no confusion.
Done
Still marking this as -1 until we resolve the discussion around the API types.
Almost 1 week from last +1. Any more comments?
